prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The spectral resolution is set just resolve the local line width (thermal + turbulent) which is typically 0.3 km/s.

An angular resolution of 0.6" (projected distance of 90au at 150 pc) is required to radially resolve the protoplanetary disks, essential in deriving radial ionization structures. Furthermore, Keplerian shear will means that all structures will be limited in size to < 3.5".

HCO+ and H13CO+ are the main goals of this Science Goal. HCO+ is bright and optically thick (10 - 20 K), so H13CO+ should be between 0.2 and 1 K given the isotopic ratio. Detection will be obtained at a high confidence level by model fitting.
The setup allows serendipitous detection of many other molecules.
The setup allows the seredenpitous detection of (or upper limits on) several interesting molecules. Spectral resolution is required for this, and only ALMA can expect to detect such lines.
The local line width is around 0.3 km/s in the conditions of disks. We matched this while still preserving the maximum aggregate bandwidth for calibration and continuum.

An angular resolution of 0.6" (projected distance of 90au at 150 pc) is required to radially resolve the protoplanetary disks, essential in deriving radial ionization structures. Furthermore, Keplerian shear will means that all structures will be limited in size to < 3.5".

the bandwidth is dictated by the local line width, which is typically 0.3 km/s at the temperature of disks. The rms is set such that N2H+ should be readily detectable. Less abundant molecules will be recovered by global model fitting, which allows to account in the best way of all the significant channels and pixels.

The setup includes many interesting lines, some absolutely essential to our goal: DCO+, N2H+, and the others which have in general never been search with such a sensitivity, but are potentially detectable. The data rate excess is worth as it avoids repeating the experiment for such a search.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The ionization structure of protoplanetary disks plays a key role in determining their physical and chemical evolution. The magneto-rotational stability, assumed to be active in sufficiently ionized rotating media, can be fundamental in facilitating the transport of mass and angular momentum in the disk. However, uncertainties in the properties of the ionization sources and the subsequent interaction of the ionizing radiation with the disk hinder our understanding of this structure and consequently the evolution of protoplanetary disks. We propose a study of six protoplanetary disks spanning a representative range of well constrained stellar X-ray properties to derive, for the first time, a radial and vertical ionization structure within the `warm molecular zone' of a protoplanetary disk.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
